results.description:
Hey everyone,

This is likely our last message via meetup, so one last time if you haven;t already please sign up for the new email list at bkentrepreneur.com.

Join us on Wednesday night the 21st at WeWork Brooklyn for a fireside chat about failure.  RSVP here.

Failure is a very big part of any journey to success.  Starting a company is often riddled with tiny failures before seeing any meaningful signs of success.  See this article if you don’t believe me.  This week we will be talking about two of the most common types of failure, co-founder conflicts, and wasting money on front-end developers.

Our first presentation will be given by Dan Vidal, CEO and founder of 2012 Mass Challenge winners, ArtVenue.  ArtVenue was a darling of the Boston startup scene that quickly gained attention with a unique approach to democratizing the art world that was later copied by IndieWalls and others.  He will discuss how a great idea and a great product quickly came unraveled due conflicting points of view with his co-founder.  

Our second presentation will be given by myself, Anthony Placet, CEO and founder of Savethatname, and also your loving host of BKE.  I will be discussing how being a non-technical founder of a tech company is a really bad idea, and one that I made.  When I founded Savethatname I only had a rudimentary understanding of HTML, and today I build all of our front facing pages from scratch using Webflow.  Learning to build pages has saved us thousands and thousands of dollars and dramatically shortened the cycle time of idea to implementation.  I will even build a website during the workshop and take questions on how and why things work the way they do.

Please join us for some drinks, if we're lucky some pizza, and tell your friends to join you.

-Anthony
results.name: Founder Fail vs Developer Fail

Because owners usually share in the future value of the company - whether in the form of profits, stock holdings, or other arrangements - decisions as to who will be an owner and his/her rights and duties should be considered carefully and spelled out precisely. • Management of the Company
• Voting Provisions including Supermajority Voting Requirements
• Restricting Transfers of Shares/Membership Interest
• Anti-dilution
• Co-sale agreement
• Valuation
• Permitted Transferees
• Buy-back Provisions
• Confidentiality, Non-compete and “Assignment of Invention” Provisions
• Dissolution
• and other common provisions

You're invited to join us for this weekly opportunity to sharpen your drawing skills! This session is open to sketchers of all levels.

What makes our sessions different? 

• We start on time in a large, clean, well-lit space. 

• Sketchers can concentrate because our room is quiet while the model is posing.

• We have coffee and cookies at the long break. 

• We finish on time so you can be headed home at 9:00 p.m sharp! 

• (Latecomers can be seated at a break.)


• This is a two hour drawing session to work from a live (nude) model.  

• We start with short 2 minute poses and work up to a 20 minute pose by the end of the session. We take a 5 minute break every 20 minutes. 


• There are seats for everyone tables and several light weight easels. 


• Access to a sink is available for watercolor artist.

• Bring your own materials (no oil or acrylic paint and no sprays please.)

As always if you have any questions please feel free to email me. I look forward to seeing you there. 

Simon

results.description:
The Plank Pizza Co is a restaurant and bar serving only craft beer and pizza in Saddle Brook. The veteran restaurant ownership has built the space using reclaimed wood, giving a modern feel to the 4500 square foot space. There’s a 162 seat dining room – second floor for overflow and private dining – plus an outdoor patio.

The food menu is pretty simple, 8 appetizers and 8 pizzas. Pizzas are made from “American sourdough”, oblong shaped (around 6″ x 12″) and cooked in a 900 degree wood-burning oven. The beer selection is pretty significant – 41 rotating (1x-2x a week) taps and a 4-1/2 page (105 bottles and growing) bottled beer list. There’s no Bud, Blue Moon, etc… only craft brews from small independents across the country.

Beer menu: https://www.beermenus.com/places/23583-the-plank-pizza-co-beer-parlor

Food Menu:

results.description:
Welcome all writers and thank you for joining!

Our agenda is as follows:

7:30-8:00 - set writing goals for upcoming week & share obstacles

8:00-8:30 - provide feedback for the chosen pieces & choose new works for following meeting

8:30-9:00 - craft discussion

9:00-9:15 - wind down & poll group

How to receive feedback:

IF you would like to be critiqued, you must attend at least one meetup to become familiar with and understand the format of the meetings. Attendees are expected to eventually submit work for feedback. In the preceding meetup we choose two writers to be critiqued. The third work is a backup if time permits. Please read them all as well as the craft essays in the "Files" section under "More" tab.

How to post:

1) Post only if you have been chosen to be critiqued and by Friday at noon. (For critique outside of meetups please post in "Pages" in the menu above.)

2) Before Posting: Long-Form Length: 3,000 words or 10 pgs max (can be shorter)

If submitting poems, max 3 a person

Double-spaced (unless for aesthetics)

11-12 point font (no smaller or larger)

Number your pages

*The organizing team maintains the right to remove pieces from circulation

3) Post in Files under More tab with this description:

- Name

- Meetup date

- Description of your work

- Type of feedback you would like

- Fiction or non-fiction specified

(As description box allows.)

When critiquing: (Always use "I" when critiquing)

1) Each person is allotted 5 mins. The writer is also allotted 5 mins to respond after everyone has spoken.

2) Share what worked and/or what you liked/ enjoyed and why.

3) Offer suggestions/ constructive criticism for improvement.

*Caffé Bene has a large assortment of coffees and teas and tasty things to eat. Please pay for your space with a purchase from the establishment.

*A listing of contests and magazines to submit to can be found on our Discussions page

See you there,
results.name: Critique, Goal Setting, & Craft Discussion

If you are planning on staying for the potluck, be sure to visit www.perfectpotluck.com to enter your food selection. By the way, the meetup page may show only a few members planning to attend a particular meeting. results.description:
Come join us for our climbing Meetup!!

As usual, everyone is welcome to join in on the fun as long as you're at least 18 years old, whether you’re a complete beginner just looking to give the sport a try or a seasoned veteran that can show the best of us a few new tricks. Bring your friends too, even if they've never tried climbing before. We'll make sure everybody is set up and having a blast. Age and strength don't even matter, everybody has fun.

1st time climbers at The Rock Club get in for FREE! All you have to do is rent a harness and shoes for $9. Returning Meetupers get a discounted daypass rate of $15. And be sure to have a look out at the gym for other special Meetup discounts.

We also host a special Meetup 101 class from 7:30 - 9pm for Meetup members only. When multiple people sign-up for the class you pay only $45 ($15 discount!).

Reserve your spot with the booking button and enter the promo code "Meetup" on the booking page.

IMPORTANT!!  This offer has restrictions. It is only valid for the Weds night Meetup 101 class, you must already be a meetup member and RSVP for the meetup as well (no guests).

If this is your first time climbing just come on in and join the group. There’s no need to take the class just yet. You’ll be able to join other Meetup members who already have their belay certification. This way you’ll be able to get up and on the wall right away! When you decide that you absolutely love climbing (which you will!), then you can sign up for the class the following week.

As a heads up, when you come into the gym, the front desk staff will get you set up with gear and get you in the system. There will also be name tags for everyone. Wear them with pride so everyone knows who’s a part of Meetup!

DETAILS - Please read carefully!

RSVPing and Questions:
If you're attending the belay course you MUST call TRC to reserve your space.
If you have any questions, please email TRC directly: [url][masked][/url]

Time:
The closer to 7pm you arrive, the better. The 101 class starts at 7:30 sharp.

Directions & Transportation:
Please save time and aggravation by getting directions from our website (BEFORE you call or email us for directions :-). If you're coming on Metro North as a group (2 or more people!) we'll pick you up from the train station. Use the message baord to connect with other riders.  Just give us a call to let us know when you'll arrive. Go to the taxi stand in front of the station building!

We're looking forward to seeing you soon!

results.description:
How signing up works: first come first serve.

The Place: Please note this restaurant does not take reservations.


This looks like amazing and traditional Polish food and had 4.5 stars on yelp with over 250 reviews:

http://www.yelp.com/biz/karczma-brooklyn

The menu is super meat heavy and I am hoping to do family style so this event is likely not suitable for vegetarians.

Menu is here: http://karczmabrooklyn.com/en/menu-2/


As always:

Please don't RSVP unless you are sure you can go. I do notice the people who RSVP and then cancel which really isn't fair to everyone else. I reserve the right to give priority to people who don't do this in the future. I'm not trying to be mean or anything but it makes it much harder for me when people take spots and then cancel either quickly or last minute. Obviously more notice is better but please try to only sign up (for waitlist as well) if you know you can come.

Also even if the meetup is full please do put your name on the waitlist. I always give priority to people on the waitlist if spots open up. I will also try to give an idea in advance if it looks like there might be more spots. Also, if there are a lot of people on the waitlist I will try to get more seats, although for reservations made far in advance I am unlikely to succeed. At very least it will let me know what kinds of restaurants are popular so I can schedule more of those in the future. Thanks.
results.name: Karczma - Polish Food

results.description:
Come and join us for an evening of fun and TurnOn. How often do we get an opportunity to be real with each other in NYC?

We play 3 communication game (you can play at whatever level feels comfortable to you). Imagine meeting new people in an environment where people felt comfortable to be themselves. That's what we have created.

It's a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation.

You get the opportunity to examine yourself. Through other people putting quality attention on you, asking questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening - really listening – to your responses.

What comes up might surprise you!

At the end of the evening we will tell you all about how you can learn the practice of Orgasmic Meditation. What class you can take and what we have to offer so you can have the life that you want.

It's amazing how connected we can end up feeling - even in a room full of strangers - when we are willing to say what's real. In an hour and some you may even forget for a moment you are in New York City.

OneTaste NYC is an organization teaches Orgasmic Meditation, otherwise known as OM. The games we play at TurnON are designed to create the visceral sensation of Orgasm/OM in your body, without having to actually do the practice (or remove any clothing!).

It's a friendly invitation to play and push your edges in a way that feels good. This allows you to stretch yourself and inspires self-discovery!

Come early, doors close at 8:10p.  

COST TO ATTEND IS $10.

For questions contact [masked] |[masked]


Can't make this one?  Visit us at www.turnonny.us

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8OWkv9zms4E
results.name: TurnON New York City

results.description:
Please check the website 'every week' for updates. meditationinnewyork.org/williamsburg-meditation-buddhism

Weekly guided meditations and Buddhist teachings in Williamsburg are suitable for both beginners and more advanced meditation practitioners.  These classes offer meditation techniques and teachings on the fundamentals of Buddhism, with an emphasis on their practical application in everyday life.

Although these meditation classes are given as a series, they can also be taken individually. Please feel free to drop in on a class-by-class basis.

Classes are held every week unless otherwise stated.
No special clothing is required. No pre-registration required.

Everyone Welcome.
results.name: Meditation in Williamsburg - Please check the website below for changes

results.description:
Having trouble fully absorbing A Course in Miracles (ACIM) or another non-dualistic spiritual tradition? Then A COURSE OF LOVE may be just for you! Channeled by the same voice that authored ACIM but in more easy to understand and feminine language, Mari Perron’s A Course of Love speaks to the heart rather than the mind. Let’s explore this important new text together and use it as a springboard to become peaceful miracle workers. Led by CRS co-founders and ACIM Teachers/Healers Yasuko Kasaki and Christopher Pelham, this class work its way through the text week by week. 

We're just starting (fall 2015) but you can join in later any time. Like yoga, it's really more experiential than progressive learning.

You can easily order the book online from Amazon or BN.com, and e-book versions are available.

It may be astonishing to hear that there is a “continuation” of A Course in Miracles, but it is true. Forty years ago Jesus dictated ACIM to the scribe Helen Schucman. More recently, over three years, he similarly dictated A Course of Love. Jesus himself referred to what he was dictating as a “continuation of A Course in Miracles.” Students of ACIM will recognize the Voice. Students of truth, whatever their background, will find that ACOL resonates with the heart.

A Course of Love builds upon the same non-dualistic thought system as ACIM, yet it is a course for the heart. ACOL and ACIM work hand-in-hand. Yet remarkably, ACOL bypasses the mind. It uses thought to go beyond thought. Those yearning to access the heart’s knowing will find help here. This is your invitation to live the purposeful, meaningful life of the new—the reality of heaven on earth.

Wednesday nights from 8 – 9:30 pm at CRS
Classes are $20 and class cards are available.
results.how_to_find_us: above Think Coffee shop (look for the brown door and ring the bottom buzzer)
results.name: Intro to A Course of Love (channeled by Mari Perron)

group.name: A Course of Love Study Group NYC

results.description:
Another great meeting last month!  For October we're reading an oldie (ish) but goodie - Into Thin Air by Jon Krakauer. 

Hope you can join us! Julie

"A bank of clouds was assembling on the not-so-distant horizon, but journalist-mountaineer Jon Krakauer, standing on the summit of Mt. Everest, saw nothing that "suggested that a murderous storm was bearing down." He was wrong. The storm, which claimed five lives and left countless more--including Krakauer's--in guilt-ridden disarray, would also provide the impetus for Into Thin Air, Krakauer's epic account of the May 1996 disaster.

By writing Into Thin Air, Krakauer may have hoped to exorcise some of his own demons and lay to rest some of the painful questions that still surround the event. He takes great pains to provide a balanced picture of the people and events he witnessed and gives due credit to the tireless and dedicated Sherpas."
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be in the 2nd floor lounge
results.name: October Bookclub

results.description:
Come and join us for an evening of fun and TurnOn. How often do we get an opportunity to be real with each other in NYC?

We play 3 communication game (you can play at whatever level feels comfortable to you). Imagine meeting new people in an environment where people felt comfortable to be themselves. That's what we have created.

It's a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation.

You get the opportunity to examine yourself. Through other people putting quality attention on you, asking questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening - really listening – to your responses.

What comes up might surprise you!

At the end of the evening we will tell you all about how you can learn the practice of Orgasmic Meditation. What class you can take and what we have to offer so you can have the life that you want.

It's amazing how connected we can end up feeling - even in a room full of strangers - when we are willing to say what's real. In an hour and some you may even forget for a moment you are in New York City.

OneTaste NYC is an organization teaches Orgasmic Meditation, otherwise known as OM. The games we play at TurnON are designed to create the visceral sensation of Orgasm/OM in your body, without having to actually do the practice (or remove any clothing!).

It's a friendly invitation to play and push your edges in a way that feels good. This allows you to stretch yourself and inspires self-discovery!

Come early, doors close at 8:10p. COST TO ATTEND IS $10.

For questions contact [masked] |[masked]

results.description:
New Swing Dance Session With Spencer @ The JCC in Manhattan

334 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY @76th street


East Coast Swing/Jitterbug with  Spencer Weisbond

This six week, progressive session:
Sept 30, 2015- Nov 4, 2015
Wed
8:30PM - 9:30PM

  101: Beginner   Learn cool moves to classic tunes! This progressive, basic swing dance class will teach the absolute beginner how to Jitterbug or what is now known as East Coast Swing. For young adults and above, this partner dance class will teach beginner moves in swing and the technique to execute them properly. The class will learn a routine over a six week period. No partner, experience, or TALENT required.

    

  Teacher: Spencer Weisbond please call me with questions about your level[masked]

  Register and pricing below:

  http://ebiz.jccmanhattan.org/personifyebusiness/Programs/ProgramDetail.aspx?pid=634125407<a href="http://ebiz.jccmanhattan.org/personifyebusiness/Programs/ProgramDetail.aspx?pid=625347764"></a>

Spencer has been dancing swing since 1998. He has studied Lindy hop extensively with 4 time world champion and 8 time American champion, Nathalie Gomes. Spencer had led the outreach program for Hop Swing And & Jump dance studios at local venues around NYC.
Spencer has had his own program in swing at the JCC in Manhattan for over 8 years, and also teaches privately. He has taught for Lincoln Center’s “Midsummer Night Swing” He currently organizes the New York City Swing Dance Meetup Group, which has over 3300 members, making it one of the most active swing dance clubs in the world. Spencer also co-founded the popular NYC dance  event “Swing Remix”. www.SwingRemix.com </a>

<a href="http://ebiz.jccmanhattan.org/personifyebusiness/Programs/ProgramDetail.aspx?pid=135408">

results.description:
Prepare for an hour of insane fun, team building, and laughter - as you are about to be trapped in a room with a zombie! (Please arrive 10-15min early. You will spend 60 min in room, with a 10 minute wrap up afterward. So budget 80-90 minutes!)

You and 11 other adventurers will enter a room and are challenged to find the clues, solve the riddles, and get the key to escape.... or get eaten. As the clock dwindles down from 60 to 0, every 5 minutes the hungry zombie's chain gets longer and the danger zone increases. Communication and teamwork are musts if you want to make it out alive.

Tickets are sold here: https://goo.gl/F1BdI0

The event concludes with a comedically insightful analysis of the group's dynamics and of individuals' contributions.

We ask that you please order tickets for a show time at least 8 HOURS PRIOR to that show time.

*Please note that the available dates listed are tentative. If the date you've selected is available, you will be signed up and your spot will be reserved (two confirmations will be emailed to you - one from Verlocal and another from our website). If it isn't, you will be contacted to choose another date!
results.name: Trapped In a Room with a ZOMBIE - Room Escape Adventures!

group.name: BEST CLUBS in NYC - FREE DRINKS every night!

results.description:
Aside from our League play we offer Open Play 6 days a week. 1 hour and 45 minute sessions only $11 midweek.

Format: 3 teams of 5 per court. Score by 1’s. Games to 7. Winner stays but must sit after 2 games. No refs. Call your own. Our moderator will help things along. All players must bring a white and a dark shirt (not grey). This is a friendly run. Anyone with the wrong attitude will not be allowed back. Age: 21+

Our open runs are designed for good fun and a run. The A / B breakdown is purely a self rating device to try and split things up in an enjoyable manner. Think of it as if you were going to the park to play. If you are average or above go to the A court. If you are average or below go to B.  It is not exact. There is always going to be some crossover.  

***Please note- RSVP'g on Meetup will not reserve your spot. Please go to our website to sign up.*** A credit card payment is required to reserve your space. Just click the session that interests you.


http://nyurban.com/open-play-basketball/

We will send you a confirmation email. Show up at the Gym with I.D. We will have you on our list but please bring your receipt. No payment at the door.
results.how_to_find_us: American Sign Language School - 225 West 23rd Street
results.name: Basketball Open Play- ASL Wednesday B-C

results.description:
Update: There are some car pools forming so whichever way you get there, be on the look out for each other  - The Javits Center opens at 10am. Want to have lunch together?...  private message each other if you need phone numbers  to meet up - the EXPO gets crazy crowded and it's easy to loose each other. 

We'll be meeting up at the Beiber Bus Terminal at the Charcoal Drive In (I suggest the 7am departure) and travel to the NYC bus station which is a short walk to the Javits Center. We can hang out together in small groups or go it alone depending on your interests that day. Most of us will depart together on the Beiber Bus. The EXPO is several days but the group will be attending on the 22nd. You are responsible to pay your bus fee and and any other EXPO fees. The EXPO itself is free if you register ahead of time - so don't wait!

Check out http://www.photoplusexpo.com for ALL the info scheduling and pricing for October 21 - October 24, 2015.

The PDN PhotoPlus International Conference + Expo is the largest photography and imaging show in North America, attended by over 22,000 professional photographers and enthusiasts. Explore over 220 exhibits, see thousands of new products, attend over 80 conference seminars, keynote presentations, special events & much more.
results.name: PDN PhotoPlus International Conference + EXPO

results.description:
Positive Connections for Success is a more relaxed and personal networking group for business professionals looking to build relationships and grow their business through referrals.

We focus on:

• Networking: Building relationships and earning each others trust to become referral partners

• Education: Understanding your business and helping you articulate your business

• Leadership: Leaders of the round table philosophy, every member is a leader of this group


We follow a structured meeting agenda starting with networking to develop relationships, giving us time to talk and get to know each other while having a warm breakfast, followed by:

• One Minute Elevator Pitch

• Business Presentations with Q&A and feedback (we have a large screen & clicker/pointer available for powerpoint presentations)

• Brainstorming Session, Successes & Referrals to Help Each Others Businesses grow

• Lots of Fun in the Process

"We Refer Business Partners, Not Business Cards!"

This is a group with category/specialty specific members (only one member per category/speciality).
Please view our sponsors page or contact us to verify your industry, category and specialty, before attending a meeting so as to not be in conflict with a group member.

We meet every Thursday morning from 7:00 AM to 8:30 AM and welcome guests to come and experience the group and then apply to join.

Non-members/guests pay a $10 fee to attend, which includes a warm served breakfast of their choosing and we ask to please be prepared with a one minute elevator pitch presenting:

• who you are

• type of business

• who would be a good referral for you


Current positions that we are interviewing, to build relationships with and pass referrals to include:

• Auto Mechanic

• Cleaning Service

• Florist

• Handyman or women

• Landscaper

• Limo or car service

• Painter

• Plumber

• And more...

Please contact us for information or if you have any questions.

We look forward to seeing you at our next meetup!
results.how_to_find_us: It's 7am, you'll see us!
results.name: Weekly Business Networking Group

Kyle, FTFC

results.description:
2nd, 3rd and 4th Thursdays of each month (except when there is a holiday) from 8:15-9:30AM we conduct our presentations, networking and business development meetings for entrepreneurs, consultants, salespeople and business owners in the NY Tri-state area. One catch – YOU bring your own coffee :-) (I will bring the bagels.)

Schedule for 2015 @AXA: 8:15-9:30AM
Thursdays @AXA, Citrin Cooperman and Ainsworth Park

Oct 8 & Lunch, 15 & Happy Hr, 22
Nov 12 & Lunch, 19 & Happy Hr, 26 is Thanksgiving (no mtg)
Dec 10 & Lunch, 17 & Happy Hr, 24

We are much more than your average meetup group. We act as your own private business advisory council and potential funding pool. Members and attendees walk out each week with sound business advice, decades worth of experience, leads and introductions.

What is an entrepreneurs breakfast /business networking and development meeting? A meeting where you present your demo, meet various people from various industries and walk out with introductions, leads and referrals and business cards. Curious how do we do this? Come on down and find out...

AXA Advisors is located at: 1290 Ave of the Americas (bet 51 - 52nd St.)
16th floor (Always check with security)

Please email or call Raphi Salem if you are interested in joining.

We charge $20.00 for all meetings (via paypal or $25 at the door) unless you become a member at $500/year. (Your first meeting is free if you just want to check it out). Please bring business cards and your own coffee. ($20 payment here through paypal: http://bit.ly/1fDv0KA)


We are part of 5 meetup groups. Please check them out and join:
http://www.meetup.com/NYC-Serious-Entrepreneurs-Only-Present-Get-Funded/
http://www.meetup.com/Entrepreneurs-NYC-Finance-Tech-Mktg-Sales-Expert-Advice/
http://www.meetup.com/Breakfast-Networking-USA/
http://www.meetup.com/NYC-Small-Business-Owners-Consultants-Salespeople/
http://www.meetup.com/Lunch-And-Focused-Networking/

We are also part of linked in. Please connect with me and join our groups:
https://www.linkedin.com/in/websitemarketing
https://www.linkedin.com/grp/home?gid=2142515
https://www.linkedin.com/grp/home?gid=2792115

Our entrepreneur panels will include engaging thought-leaders such as Vera of <a>Vera Moore Cosmetics</a>, Deborah Koenigsberger of <a>Hearts of Gold Foundation</a>, Genese Jamilah of <a>I Don't Do Clubs</a>, and many more!

AGENDA

Black Entrepreneurs Summit 2015 will be an immersive and invaluable experience taking place in one action-packed morning at the beautiful Terrace Club in Manhattan.

Each session will be made up of engaging keynote presentations and panels from some of the brightest and successful Black Entrepreneurs in the city

8:00am     Check-In & Networking

results.description:
Join us for the FIRST EVER Inside Startups Breakfast Club!

Come hang with fellow creatives and entrepreneurs at Projective Space's new communal work/event space upstairs at Freemans Restaurant. 

We'll spare no expense on Colombe Coffee, Doughnut Plant donuts and mimosas (because those three combined will equal a fun and productive Thursday).

For anyone working in, or interested in, the local startup scene: don't miss this. If you've never before been to a Meetup: you should be here too.

SPACE IS LIMITED.

RSVP today and invite your friends!

** SPECIAL GUEST **

Leo Widrich, Co-Founder/COO of Buffer, will join us to share about his story, Buffer's team, talk about job opportunities and answer any questions. Prior to, learn more about Leo: click here & here. @LeoWid @buffer

Since 2011, Inside Startups has connected great people with cool job opportunities in the startup scene by hosting events, sending a weekly newsletter and managing a directory with 600+ startups: insidestartups.org

Based in NYC, Inside Startups is run by Ali Nicolas, former VP People at OMGPOP. The founder is Dan Porter, former President of Teach for America, SVP Corp Dev at Virgin USA and CEO of OMGPOP. results.description:
October: What is a #hashtag anyway?

From Bitly to Blogging: Social media explored October 22

Last month’s interactive social media workshop was such a hit, with so much positive feedback, that we decided to repeat it this month, although with a different presenter and a different twist.

In September, we focused on the importance of blogging, and some topic ideas that you can use. The most important aspect of all your social media campaigns is creating original content to drive people to your web site so that your SEO increases. (Search engine optimization) Translated, this means that you will show high when someone does a Google search for a product or service you offer.

On October 22, we will be treated to a presentation by Rupa Kale, a Summit/New Providence B.I.G. member who owns Bottle & Bottega in Berkeley Heights and who just earned a prestigious social media marketing award by her company. Our meeting will be from 10-11:30 at Twin Maples, 214 Springfield Ave. in Summit.

Last month we had over 25 people attend. We expect at least that this month. With such a nice-sized group, there is going to be a vast range in the amount of knowledge of the women in the room. That is a good thing. While some of us were able to share the best URL shortener and link management platforms, others were asking what a hash tag is. The beauty of BIG is that we can all help and support each other! The content of the meeting will be driven by what the people present want to know.

Plan on joining us for lunch at a local restaurant following the meeting! RSVP to [masked] or for any questions.
results.name: B.I.G. Social Media Discussion!

results.description:
The first public high school opened its doors 200 years ago. It was based on the belief that high school, if free and available, would develop graduates who would contribute to culture, society and the economy.


https://www.youtube.com/embed/JGBkqkorwxw

100 years after its inception, the system was overhauled to meet the demands of an industrialized society. 

High School Education has stayed frozen ever since.

</a> https://youtu.be/h8Fv3QmsYQk

Radical change is long overdue. We need to rethink the beliefs and the models which we’ve built these schools. We need to plan for a future where ideas are currency, where knowledge is highly valued.

<a href="http://magazine.good.is/videos/xq-super-school">Read More.. http://magazine.good.is/videos/xq-super-school
results.name: Thinking of A Revolution...

https://youtu.be/-Sm0rL8HrRM

About 100 years after its inception, the system was overhauled to meet the demands of an industrialized, factory-based society. And it has stayed frozen in time ever since. https://youtu.be/JGBkqkorwxw

Radical and meaningful change is long overdue. We need to rethink the beliefs and the models upon which we’ve built these schools. We need to plan for a future where ideas are currency, where knowledge is highly valued. Read More.. http://magazine.good.is/videos/xq-super-school

results.description:
EVENT DATE: Oct 22, 2015

Do you want to climb 4 World Trade Center? 68 floors. 1632 steps. A party at the top. Do it for the kids.​

Register at: https://www.crowdrise.com/AllStarClimb4Kids

Take the challenge: All-Star Climb 4 Kids.

The Date

Thursday, October 22, 2015

The Location

4 World Trade Center

The Climb

68 Floors. 1632 steps.  Walk or run to the top.

The Time

Registration Opens at 4:00 pm

Climb Starts at 5:00 pm

Celebration begins at 5:30 pm

The Celebration

We invite our climbers, virtual climbers, and sponsors for a celebration on the 68th Floor of 4 WTC with DJ Peter Rosenberg of Hot 97!

The Crowd

Anyone/everyone in the world is invited to the Climb4Kids

The Price

Fundraising minimum is $350

Not able to climb?

We still want you there- register as a “virtual climber” and take the elevator!

The Deadline To Sign-Up

October 18, 2015

For the past few months After-School All-Stars has been dreaming up a big, bold event that would help us raise cash to support our rapidly expanding programs in Newark and New York. We toyed with a few traditional ideas—cocktail reception, gala—before it dawned on us that we should be holding a fitness event that mirrors the challenge we pose to our All-Stars every day. We ask our All-Stars to dream big. We ask them to reach for the stars. We teach them to make healthy lifestyle choices and challenge them to engage in physical activity on a daily basis.

So why not issue the same challenge to our incredibly loyal network of supporters?

The All-Star Climb 4 Kids is like no fundraising event you’ve been a part of. If you’ve ever wanted to do more than write a check to support your favorite cause, here is your chance to get really involved. If you’re looking for motivation to stay fit after the summer ends but before the holidays begin, the climb couldn’t land at a better time. If you need an excuse to meet up with friends, here is your chance to train and compete together.  If climbing to the 68th floor of a really tall building (4 World Trade Center!) is on your bucket list, well, here’s your chance to scratch it from the list! If you’re an avid stair climber hungry for a fall challenge, this event has your name written all over it.  

Are you ready for the challenge?
results.name: Be ready to climb!

results.description:
Weather: Please check back here for any weather updates and/or cancellations.

Transit: 2 or 5 trains to E 174th St stop and short walk. 5 train runs express until 7PM from E 149th St-Third Ave to E 180th St. BX17, BX21 and BX11 within walking distance.

Ready? Play.
_____________________________________________________

What will we be doing at the Meetup?
We will be meeting at the tennis courts for some friendly rallying, doubles, and singles play*. This meetup is open to players at any skill level; from beginner to advanced.

*For those of you who are interested in singles play, please keep in mind that the ability to play singles predicates on the amount of members who have RSVPed as well as court availability at the meetup event's venue. We cannot guarantee singles play in every instance.

How long will the meetup be?
The time listed for the meetup event is when you can expect to the event host to be there. If you would like to arrive earlier or later than the start time listed, please leave a comment in the meetup event you plan to attend. This will give everyone in attendance a good representation of who is showing up at what time.

What will it be like?
Our group is very friendly and loosely organized to allow for a fun experience.

Upon arrival, our event host will announce which court they are on in the comments of the meetup event. If you have a smartphone, we strongly suggest that you download the Meetup app for iPhone or Android to make communication easier.

When you arrive at the courts, look for the event host listed or other members of the group playing on (or near) the courts listed. Use the photos of each host/member on the website as a frame of reference.


Introduce yourself. Let the host know your level of play and you will be assigned to a court immediately.

Do members need to bring anything?
All members must bring their own racquet. Unfortunately, we do not supply racquets.

All members are encouraged to bring a fresh can of new balls. You can always use a marker to mark your initials on your ball if you would like to keep them for future play. Please keep in mind that tennis balls only last a couple of days after taking them out of the can before they lose their bounce.

If you plan to donate to the group, you can leave your donation with the meetup event host or the head organizer, Frank, if he’s in attendance. All donations go towards the fees required to organize the meetup.

Who should come? Are newcomers welcome?
Our meetup event is open to all players whether they're an absolute beginner or an advanced player. Players will be matched up with others based on their skill level. Beginners will be given an opportunity to play with higher level players so they can gain more experience with higher consistency.

It is a high priority for our group to help beginners increase their skill and become better players. If you are reading this and are an absolute beginner, please don't be intimidated. We want you to join us and have fun.

What should a newcomer expect?
If you're new to the group, you'll learn very quickly that our community is extremely friendly. We have a colorful cast of characters from all walks of life who are ready and willing to have a good time.

Whether you're interested in easy-going rallying or competitive play, we can accommodate you.

Questions?
If you have any other questions, concerns, or comments; please send them to our head organizer, Frank Tirado via email.

results.description:
Join DM Kyle Wagenblast as he recreates the classic D&D 2E module "Adam's Wrath" by Lisa Smedman. This is an adventure in the Ravenloft setting, updated to D&D 5E, and is for characters of 5th level.

In the domain of Lamordia, Doctor Victor Mordenheim created Adam, cobbling the creature together from parts of human corpses. Now, years later, Adam wants revenge. Adam wants Elise, Victor's wife. Adam wants Victor dead.

The players' ship founders on the coast of the domain of Lamordia. A vicious storm leaves them washed ashore, cold and hungry on the ice-bound Isle of Agony... then, the terror begins.
results.name: D&D 5E: Ravenloft - Adam's Wrath

results.description:
Come join KPMG and Hortonworks to discuss the concepts of Hadoop-based Data Lake and its relevancy from three related viewpoints. This will be a great opportunity to mingle with the KPMG and Hortonworks teams along with your fellow big data software engineers and data scientist peers to exchange ideas and knowledge of each other’s industries. This session includes a demonstration of ‘DStreams’ (Distributed Streams), a project currently under construction at Hortonworks.

1. Learn about the general benefits and challenges of a centralized architecture associated with a Data Lake

2. Discuss use cases that leverage a Data Lake coming from the financial services vertical

3. Hortonworks will be demoing and discussing a new technology project designed to make processing data more streamlined, and facilitate greater reusability and reduced time to solution through improved abstractions and configurability


Speakers:

Kevin Martelli- Director, Data & Analytics- KPMG

Tim Cerino- Director, Data & Analytics- KPMG

Owen Taylor- Solutions Engineer- Hortonworks

Vamsi Chemitiganti- General Manger, Financial Services, Hortonworks

Oleg Zhurakousky- Principal Architect, Hortonworks

All participants must check in at the KPMG Heritage Center located on the Lobby Level of the Lexington side of building. Please bring a photo id and a temporary access badge will be provided to you.  Once checked in, proceed to the elevator bank and go to the 37th floor and specifically to room CC3-ABC.
results.how_to_find_us: 37th Floor
results.name: Hadoop-based Data Lake- Beverages & Pizza

venue.name: The Elizabeth Foundation for the Arts

results.description:
This page has images, so if you dont see them and you are........

1) viewing this page on the Meetup app click the description tab to view the list of galley openings.  

2) using an Android mobile browser open your browser's settings menu and click ''Request Desktop Site". 

3) using  Apple IOS then click the desktop site button at the bottom of the page. 

For those new to the Hop you might be wondering how you will find the group. Well below is a lovely picture  of myself. Study my face carefully and commit it to memory. Now that I am burned into your hippocampus simply look for me hovering near the entrance of  323 West 39th street.

Todd (Eyewear has changed but the face remains the same) 

Just a little more business...

Every week I receive emails from new members asking if there is a fee to join or attend the Thursday Night Gallery Hop. So rather than answer each email individually I'll kill a whole flock of birds with one stone.  

THE HOP IS, ALWAYS HAS BEEN, AND WILL REMAIN COMPLETELY FREE 

That said if you would like to help offset my organizer fees or buy me a post-hop bourbon you are more than welcome to click the 'chip in' button on the left side of this page. But let me reiterate contributions while appreciated are NOT required. 

And now........

The Elizabeth Foundation Open Studios 2015

is an annual event of the EFA Studio Program that invites the public to come explore and interact with our member artists in the intimate setting of their studios. It is an opportunity to see the most recent works by artists at the site of their origin and to gain meaningful insight into their process of creation. The EFA Studio Program is a vibrant and diverse community of over 75 artists working in a wide range of media and artistic sensibilities. All are professional artists with an established studio practice and recognized career. Rarely can curators, collectors, dealers, artists, and art lovers see so many internationally recognized artists working under one roof in Midtown Manhattan. For more information visit

http://www.studios-efanyc.org/open-studios/ PARTICIPATING ARTISTS: Samira Abbassy, Lucas Ajemian, William Allen, Clytie Alexander, Richard Barnes, Keren Benbenisty, Maria Berrio, Wafaa Bilal, Rhona Bitner, Jessie Brugger, Martha Burgess, Patty Cateura, Noa Charuvi, Heejung Cho, Cecile Chong, Vicky Colombet, Michael Eade, Stella Ebner, Sally Egbert, Jonathan Ehrenberg, Sean Fader, Cui Fei, Angela Fraleigh, Beth Ganz, Del Geist, Tai Hwa Goh, Lauren Gohara, Kira Nam Greene, Mahmoud Hamadani, Richard Hart, Pablo Helguera, Amy Hill, Catherine Howe, Eunjung Hwang, Hong Seon Jang, Edgar Jerins, Richard Jochum, Tamiko Kawata, Yongjae Kim, Noah Klersfeld, Greg Kwiatek, Sarah Leahy, Patricia Leighton, J.C. Lenochan, Patte Loper, Dominic Mangila, Katinka Mann, Jeanette May, Toyin Odutola, Morgan O’Hara, Thomas Pihl, Shahpour Pouyan, Armita Raafat, Max Razdow, Javier Romero, Charlotte Schulz, Hilda Shen, Gabriel J. Shuldiner, Karina Skvirsky, Howard Smith, Xin Song, Steed Taylor, Dannielle Tegeder, Scott Teplin, Yuken Teruya, Hank Willis Thomas, Denise Treizman, Liselot van der Heijden, Carlos Vega, Marjorie Welish, Bryan Whitney, Saya Woolfalk, Shia Zurim

About EFA Studio Program: Founded in 1998 as a program of the Elizabeth Foundation for the Arts, the EFA Studio Program was created to provide affordable studio space within a community of artists, facilitate career development, and promote public and critical exposure for our members. EFA Studios is housed on eight floors of the EFA building located in Midtown Manhattan’s Fashion District, in close proximity to the city’s primary gallery districts. Members are selected by a jury of respected arts professionals, through a competitive application process. EFA Studios facilitates interaction with dealers, curators, and critics to provide continued development for member-artists. Unique among studio programs in New York City, EFA Studios is one of the few remaining arts organizations still providing long-term workspace in Manhattan.

After the Hop everyone who would like to continue with the group are welcome to join us at a nearby restaurant (location TBD) for refreshments and general merriment.  

Look forward to seeing everyone

Todd
results.how_to_find_us: We'll meet in front of the 323 W 39th, at 6:15 we'll head into the EFA, there are 75 studios spread over multiple floors so the group WILL break apart, but worry not :) at 9:15 those who want to get dinner should regroup in the lobby
results.name: The Elizabeth Foundation for the Arts Open Studios 2015

results.description:
Manhattan Toastmasters' General Meeting is scheduled for Thursday, October 22, 2015. We would like to welcome guests to attend this meeting. You will get to experience awesome speeches by our Manhattan Toastmasters Club members as well gain some experience speaking in front of a group. 

Our meetings are divided into three sections. The first section consists of project speeches, delivered by our Club Members. The second section features Table Topics, where Club Members and Guests get a chance to practice impromptu speaking. The third section includes Evaluations, when the project speakers receive constructive feedback from the evaluators. 

Come and join us for our General meeting and take the first step in improving your public speaking skills, gain confidence and make new friends who will support and encourage you.

AFTER-PARTY immediately after the meeting we will socialize at The Upstairs Pub located on the 2nd Floor of Everyday Gourmet Cafe (corner of 41st & Lexington)
results.name: Oct 22 - General Meeting

results.description:
Overview:

Everyone is making content but few are connecting the dots to to build a machine that will help qualify your prospects and get the right people into your sales funnel. 

You will learn:

- Actionable steps towards building your content strategy
- The latest trends in content marketing
- Take home resources for content managment 

About the Speaker:

Michael Rovner

@RovnerMichael is a Co-founder at Mr. Finn Content Works, a columnist for Inc.com, The Association of National Advertisers, and an instructor at General Assembly. He speaks regularly on the subject of content marketing. As a journalist, he began writing for The New York Times, Esquire, and Vogue, and he helped launch a half-dozen national magazines.

Michael will take viewers through the basics of content marketing including goals like traffic, leads and conversion. 

About the Venue:

Thank you to our partner Wix.com for hosting us at the Wix Lounge. Wix.com enables you to build a free and professional online presence, just the way you want it. With an HTML5 drag-and-drop website editor, 100s of web apps, designer-made templates, and tons of features, Wix gives you the tools to launch and manage your online presence.

So what are you waiting for? Sign up for a free Wix workshop today!
results.name: Content Marketing: Drive Traffic to your brand!

results.description:
Advocates of peace are dismayed at President Barack Obama's recent decision to not withdraw US Troops from Afghanistan. The progressive wisdom is that present blowback, in the form of Isis, is partly a result of US entanglement in Afghanistan in the first place.

Please come to the Humanist Meeting this Thursday for a presentation by and discussion with author Jean-Louis Bourgeois. Bourgeois describes the labyrinthine caverns that have, over the centuries, made military assaults upon Afghanistan futile. He will tell stories from personal experience, and relate his firsthand account of the courage and resolve of the peoples of the region.

We meet at 6:00 PM for socializing and dinner ordered from the Moonstruck menu.  We usually proceed to our discussion by 7:00 PM.  Please feel free to come at any time.

We value the benefit of your wisdom and your contribution to the discussion. Hoping to see you and your friends this Thursday.

The Space Frontier Foundation’s NewSpace Business Plan Competition (BPC), which awards seed money, announced that the first two of five total regional, qualifying competitions for the 2015/2016 competition cycle will be held in New York on October 22, 2015 and Los Angeles on December 3, 2015. The cities will each host a Shark Tank-style event whose winners will advance to the national competition in Seattle.

The Northeastern Regional Winner will receive an all expenses paid trip to the BPC Grand Final at the NewSpace 2016 Conference in Seattle. The Grand Final Prize has been as much as $100,000 in previous NewSpace BPC competitions.

NEW LOCATION FOR THIS EVENT: It will be held in the Feliciano School of Business building, room 101 (auditorium) with registration in the first floor atrium, by the main entrance. See map below--Feliciano building is dark blue; Red Hawk Deck is in red.

Click for important parking info about this event.

Event is free, and food will be served!

Edie Weiner, a renowned futurist, will keynote this event and moderate a panel of women leaders in the health care space.


The panelists will look far into the future to predict what might be happening in exciting tech-related areas.


What is the future of robot caretakers in Japan and beyond? Julie Bauer, president of Panasonic Consumer Corp. of North America, will give us the scoop and talk about how the company – a world leader in robotics – is developing medical robots to help with patient care.

Looking ahead with regard to genomics, the average person will throw off 1.2 or 1.3 terabytes of data – how is any human going to be able to process all of that data and make it useful to clinicians at the point of care? Louisa Roberts, associate partner at IBM Watson Life Sciences, will discuss how Watson – the computer that beat geniuses on Jeopardy! – will be able to democratize health care and help prevent disease before it materializes.

How might sensory stimulation, including taste and smell, be impacted by health care in the future? Tina Garyantes, an expert in sensory science and VP of Innovation at Chromocell, will fill us in.


Join us as we travel forward in time – to 2020 and beyond - to have a peek at the future of health care.


Keynote speaker and moderator: Edie Weiner, president and CEO, The Future Hunters

</a> Panelists:
<a href="http://www.montclair.edu/entrepreneur/womens-entrepreneurship-week/guest-speakers/bauerj/">Julie Bauer, president of Panasonic Consumer Corp. of North America
Tina Garyantes, VP of Innovation, Chromocell
Louisa Roberts, associate partner, IBM Watson Life Sciences

For speaker bios, please visit WomenEntrepreneurshipWeek.com

Event is free, and food will be served!


Agenda:
6-6:45 p.m. Networking with pizza
6:45-7 p.m. Welcome remarks and 1-minute pitches from audience
7-7:20 p.m. Edie Weiner keynote address with audience Q&A
7:20-8:10 p.m. Panel discussion with audience Q&A
8:10-8:30 p.m. Final comments by Edie Weiner

This event is part of the second annual Women Entrepreneurship Week, a celebration throughout New Jersey during the week of Oct. 19. Other events at Montclair State include "In Style: Women Entrepreneurs in the Fashion and Beauty Industries" event on Oct. 19 and the "Women Entrepreneurship Week Conference" on Oct. 21. results.description:
A twist on a talent show. 
You don't need to put on a show for us. 
YOU are talent. 
And, we want to experience you. 

Come and share yourself, your expression, your creativity, your passions, your ideas, your stories, what makes you... you.

You are free to be... 
raw 
bold 
colorful 
vulnerable. 

It doesn't have to be over the top. It definitely isn't meant to be perfect. We are gathering to be curious, open-minded, to connect, and to delight in the multi-faceted spectrum of who we are. 

You can soak in the atmosphere from the audience or share who you are with us on stage. 

The sign-up is open mic style. When you arrive, just put your name down and you'll have up to 4 minutes to share. 

We will start at 6:30 pm and the show will end 7:45 pm, but afterwards we will be hanging out inside or in the back garden area depending on the weather. 

The show is free with an optional $5 suggested donation from the venue who is so generously hosting us. Also, the bar will be open with drinks and some yummy edibles too, so please plan to support the venue when joining us. 


p.s. If you're on the fence about sharing something, please feel free to reach out via message for feedback / encouragement. We'd love to hear from you!

As examples: there have been stories, readings from a journal, free-style rap in Chinese, original songs with a Ukulele, and spontaneous expressions. There is no right or wrong. We want your truth in whichever form it wants to be shared!

results.description:
Presented by ASRC and NYCS

What is life? How did life start on planet earth 3.5 billion years ago, and which molecules / chemical systems lead to biology? Could evolution be the ultimate creationist? Is there are general theory of evolution that extends to all matter? Can we make or evolve life from scratch in a matter of hours? These are fantastically interesting questions but in this lecture, rather than look back into the past, we will look to the future and discuss how chemists may go about creating new types of truly synthetic (artificial or inorganic biology). In embarking upon this quest we will be asking the question “What is the minimal chemical system that can undergo Darwinian evolution?” and in doing so looking towards the concept of ‘adaptive matter’ and evolvable materials and chemical systems. The aim is inorganic biology, or more simply, a living system that does not the current chemical infrastructure utilized by biology.

We will not only discuss abstract concepts, but real chemistry and experiments that we have constructed in Glasgow, see the photo below. Importantly a rigorous experimental approach will be debated that will allow peers to scrutinize and test the validity of our approach to the production of autonomous chemical entities capable of replication and adaptive behavior.

Reception: starts 6.00
Lecture start time: 7.30
Close: 8.30

Refreshments and drinks included.

Lee Cronin FRSE. Professional Career: 2013-Regius Professor of Chemistry. Alexander von Humboldt research fellow (Uni. of Bielefeld);[masked]: Research fellow (Uni. of Edinburgh); 1997: Ph.D. Bio-Inorganic Chemistry, Uni. of York; 1994 BSc. Chemistry, First Class, Uni. of York. Prizes include 2015 RSC Tilden Prize, 2013 BP/RSE Hutton Prize, 2012 RSC Corday Morgan, 2011 RSC Bob Hay Lectureship, a Wolfson-Royal Society Merit Award in 2009, Election to the Royal Society of Edinburgh in 2009. The focus of Cronin’s work is understanding and controlling self-assembly and self-organisation in Chemistry to develop functional molecular and nano-molecular chemical systems (including solar fuel systems); linking architectural design with function and recently engineering system-level functions (e.g. coupled catalytic self-assembly, emergence of inorganic materials and fabrication of inorganic cells that allow complex cooperative behaviours). Much of this work is converging on exploring the assembly and engineering of emergent chemical systems aiming towards ‘inorganic biology’. This work has been presented in over 320 papers and 280 lectures worldwide. It is also worth pointing out that the expertise in the Cronin group (which numbers over 50 people and > £10 M in funding) is unique bringing together inorganic / synthetic chemists, chemical engineers, flow chemistry, digital chemistry, complex system modelling, evolutionary theory, robotics and AI.
results.name: The Evolutionary Genesis Engine - An Evening With Lee Cronin (Lecture 7:30pm)

Are you trying to break into product management? Come learn how to get that first PM job. We'll also cover how to grow your career once you're a product manager.  Our panel of PM experts will share advice and answer questions.

We plan to have an interactive discussion and will be crowdsourcing and answering questions from the audience in real time.

6:45 - 7:45 pm - Panel Discussion

7:45 - 8:30 pm - Networking

Takeaways:

Meet the Panelists:   

Carlos González de Villaumbrosia is the CEO of Product School. He has 8 years of experience building teams and digital products on 3 continents. He is a three times company Co-founder. Before Product School, he was the Lead Instructor of Product Management at General Assembly and Co-founder and CEO of Floqq (invested by 500Startups), the biggest marketplace for online video courses in Latin America.

He is also the Product Management Instructor at Product School in New York.

results.description:
The Beginner Buddhist Book Circle is for anyone interested in or new to Buddhism. In this biweekly series, we’ll explore classic introductory Buddhist books. Although we have “reading assignments”, the meetings focus more on basic Buddhist teachings rather than strict discussions of the books. Our meetings are casual and informal; all levels of interest and experience are welcome. When possible, we’ll have copies of the current book available at no cost. Meetings occur on the second Wednesday and fourth Thursday of the month unless otherwise noted. Please see the Meetup page and calendar for the full schedule.

*** Right Now We’re Reading: “The Heart of the Buddha's Teachings" by Thich Nhat Hanh***

In "The Heart of the Buddha's Teachings", renowned Vietnamese Buddhist monk, teacher, poet, and peace activist Thich Nhat Hanh (Thay) presents the essentials of Buddhist teachings in a clear, compassionate, and concise manner. In addition to covering teachings at the core of all Buddhist traditions, Thay also covers many key Mahayana Buddhist teachings. In all discussions, Thay helps guide us to the heart of what the Buddha taught; the transformation of suffering into peace, joy, and liberation.

First released in 1999, "The Heart of the Buddha's Teachings" has become a classic and essential read for anyone interested in learning more about basic Buddhist teachings. The book is widely available in bookstores and libraries in print, ebook form, and audio book form.


For the Oct. 22nd meeting, please read Chapters 5 through 7.

Discussion points include:

-What exactly do Buddhist mean by "suffering"?


-A (very!) basic overview of meditation practices


-How can understand the Four Noble Truths enhance our practice?


***

Happy reading and we hope to see you soon!
results.name: Beginner Buddhist Book Circle

1. Executive Summary

2. Problem

3. Your Solution

4. Market Size / Customer Base

5. Competition

6. Revenue Model

7. Go to Market Strategy


8. Projections

9. Product Development Timeline/ Progress to Date

10. Team

The Bi Book Club meets once a month to discuss bi-themed books and the issues they raise. Dinner after nearby-we usually go to Village Den on Greenwich Ave behind the Center.

Our book for Oct is a memoir, Call It Wonder: an odyssey of love, sex. spirit, and travel by Kate Evans, on sale at BGSQD, or can be ordered if they run out.

Pick out some phrases, paragraphs or scenes that you'd like to discuss. Give us your critique of the book. What worked, what didnt, how was bisexuality represented? If you havent had time to finish the readings, come anyway because we read passages from the book aloud for discussion. As usual, we'll also be using the text as a jumping off point to further discussion of bisexual issues and personal experiences.

Deciding Books: We will be voting on what books we want to read next, so check the list of Bisexual Book Award finalists or 2015 bi books for some ideas.

Venue: Bureau of General Services Queer Division Bookstore at the LGBT Center, 2nd fl. Rm. 210, phone (646) 457-0859.

Getting Books: We urge you to purchase your print copy at BGSQD and support the only LGBT bookstore in New York City. Especially since they are hosting us in their space! If they are out of stock, put in your special order.

Bi Book Club meets 4th Thursdays 6:30-8pm. Nov & Dec dates will not be on 4th Thurs due to the holidays--alternative dates in Nov & Dec are being scheduled. Dinner after nearby-we usually go to Village Den on Greenwich Ave behind the Center.

Fees: Donation to help pay rent

Questions? Email fuscialadybug (at) netzero (dot) com or call[masked]

results.description:
ABSTRACT


In spite of growing popularity of data visualization, the major problem in business communication is yet to be solved. Most business reports still fall somewhere between messy spreadsheets and dashboards, that simply do not get the message across to the decision-makers. Countless reports and presentations are created throughout organizations daily, all in different formats, lengths, shapes and colors, depending on personal preferences of the person who prepares them. 


Dr. Hichert’s International Business Communication Standards (IBCS) are world’s first proposal for a standardized design of business communication. IBCS consistently defines shapes and colors of actuals and budgets, variances, different KPIs, etc. The “traffic signs for management” are an extensive set of rules and recommendations that went viral in Europe and have solved business communication problems in companies such as SAP, Coca-Cola bottlers, Bayer, Lufthansa, BMW, Philips, etc.


The IBCS standards are not just about charts. They help


(1) organize and structure your content by using an appropriate storyline,

(2) present your content by using an appropriate visual design and


(3) standardize the content by using a consistent,uniform notation.


We'll present the key features of IBCS through real-world examples


(https://zebra.bi/gallery/)

and discuss their slightly controversial proposition: the design of business information should look (more or less) the same across all companies, regardless of their size, industry or location.


BIO

Andrej Lapajne, CEO at Zebra BI (https://zebra.bi), is a founding member of the IBCS Association (http://ibcs-a.org) and one of Dr. Hichert's closest associates. In his 15 years of experience as a consultant, he's helped 50+ international and regional companies achieve consistent and efficient internal reporting throughout the organisation. He's implemented reporting systems and business intelligence dashboards in pharma, telco, retail, FMCG, manufacturing, insurance, banking, energy, media, public sector and high tech industries.

Andrej is a lecturer on information design at Faculty of Economics and Faculty of Computer Science and Informatics in Ljubljana. He's a frequent speaker at European conferences, utterly passionate about data visualization.
results.name: Dr. Hichert's IBCS: Designing reports, dashboards and presentations

Free T-shirts/swag, fun-drinks & junk-food + win an Apple Watch!

Jurgis Orups, Co-Founder & CTO, Clusterpoint


RSVP NOW: http://www.NYCSQL.com/events/225397952/

A Database Month event:


http://www.DatabaseMonth.com/database/database-computing

Databases are typically utilized for storing data, but data is only useful if it is being turned into actionable insights. In this session we will explore an important adjacent-role of the database, to efficiently perform computations and create derived data.

Relational databases have been successful for several decades now because they provide a well defined computational framework, which is built on top of relational algebra. The relational algebra defines a set of operations that can be performed on the data.

However, times change and we are presently in a situation where relational databases do not easily scale to the amounts of data that businesses and organizations around the world are dealing with. NoSQL technology has emerged as an attempt to address this, but NoSQL loses the computational aspect. The majority of NoSQL databases are glorified key-value stores that support CRUD operations, but do not define a solid computational model.

Alternatively, MapReduce defines a computational framework to process large amounts of data, but has its own caveats. It encourages batch processing and full-scans of data, so the computation becomes detached from stored data.

It is our belief that the data management industry will move into the direction of consolidating storage, which will allow computing power and new databases to emerge; these will both scale to data storage needs as well as provide a solid online computational framework.

This session will teach you about a computing engine that is built into the database and allows arbitrary JavaScript-based code to be executed directly in the database, next to the data.

This setup provides a simple and powerful computational model that ensures data is accessed through efficient indices directly in the database, thus massively accelerating data manipulation operations.

Throughout this talk, we will present examples of how advanced computation can be done directly in the database, including an analysis of geospatial data, and the application of statistical model-like logistic regression to derive predictions.

Jurgis Orups, Co-Founder & CTO, Clusterpoint

Jurgis co-founded Clusterpoint in 2006.

Prior to that, he spent 6-years managing a team building large-scale Internet crawler and search technology. He specializes in parallel computing, text retrieval algorithms and natural language processing.

Jurgis has an MSc in Computer Science from the University of Latvia. When not at work, he enjoys photography and mountain biking, and even keeps a training bike in the office.

RSVP: http://www.NYCSQL.com/events/225397952/

Presentation starts at 6:40pm

results.description:
Whether you are an experienced IP practitioner or a corporate generalist, understanding key considerations in litigating and resolving patent disputes will likely prove useful at one or more points in your in-house career.  These days, many patent disputes are litigated before the Patent Trial and Appeal Board (PTAB) in the U.S. Patent & Trademark Office, as either an inter partes review (IPR) or covered business method (CBM) review. 

This presentation will address key steps companies and their counsel should take to prepare for and manage PTAB proceedings effectively.  Our speaker, Charles Macedo, partner at the IP litigation specialty firm of Amster Rothstein & Ebenstein, will discuss preparation and prosecution of PTAB proceedings, including such strategic considerations as:

•  Determining whether to join with others, file your own petition, or wait and see;

• Considerations as to type, content, timing, and number of petitions;

• Selecting counsel and declarants and allocating resources;

• Anticipating defenses and addressing them upfront; and

• Understanding what resources are needed for the various steps of the process.

Regardless of your prior level of patent knowledge, you will come away from this program with key information that can help prepare your company for a patent dispute before the PTAB. 

Registration begins at 6:30 PM.

The presentation will be given from 7:00 PM to 8:00 PM. 

A networking cocktail reception will follow the presentation, courtesy of the firm.

This course has been approved for 1.0 NY General Practice CLE credit.
results.name: CLE | Preparing for a Dispute Before the Patent Trial and Appeal Board

results.description:
Events are intended for people who identify as women women unless otherwise noted and are always open to trans gender women. Our Code of Conduct applies to all events run by Women Who Code, Inc.

HOST: 

Betterment is the fastest-growing automated investing service, helping people to better manage, protect, and grow their wealth through smarter technology. The service offers a globally diversified portfolio of ETFs, designed to help provide you with the best possible expected returns for retirement planning, building wealth, and other savings goals. Betterment is a CNBC Disruptor 50 and Webby award winner and has been featured in the New York Times, Forbes, and the Wall Street Journal. Betterment helps people to achieve a smarter financial future with minimal effort and for a fraction of the cost of traditional financial services.

DESCRIPTION:

This monthly meetup covers algorithms. We'll split attendees into two main groups:

Whiteboarding skills : You'll solve algorithms in small groups, breaking off into your preferred programming language and working together to find a solution. Problems are provided and vary in difficulty, check out the Github for examples of past problems: https://github.com/WomenWhoCodeNYC/Algorithms

Beginners : You'll pair with other members and practice answering easier algo questions. This group will be led by a more experienced developer who will help you out when you get stuck.

Schedule: 
6:30 Arrive/Network/Food 
7:00 Welcome from Women Who Code 
7:05 Welcome from Betterment and a short talk on interviewing from Aruna Sooknarine
7:15 Meetup starts 
9:30 Event ends after solution presentation from volunteers

Resources:  

The WWCNYC Github contains questions (and solutions) from past events, as well as upcoming problems! Submit solutions, contribute interview questions and more: https://github.com/WomenWhoCodeNYC/Algorithms

Other resources: 

http://www.ocf.berkeley.edu/~kelu/interviews/questions.html
http://katemats.com/interview-questions/
http://meetupresources.herokuapp.com/index.html
http://codingforinterviews.com/practice

Resources for beginners or anyone who needs to review:

http://code.tutsplus.com/tutorials/algorithms-and-data-structures--cms-20437
http://www.nczonline.net/blog/tag/algorithms/

For our beginners, we recommend creating accounts on either http://jsbin.com/ or http://codepen.io/, to give you an place to practice your algorithms problem-solving skills.

results.description:
Are you interested in contributing to open source software? Do you already contribute to OSS and want to hear about the experiences of other contributors and the projects they work on? Write/Speak/Code NYC and PyLadies NYC present a panel of five open source contributors who will share their experiences in OSS: how they got started contributing, the types of projects they hack on, and more.

Doors 6:30pm
Panel 7pm 

If you have already RSVP'ed via PyLadies NYC, please don't RSVP again here. That way, someone else can also have a spot. Thanks!


Anna Herlihy
==========
Anna Herlihy is a software engineer specializing in Python. She works on PyMongo, Monary, and a few other open source projects (mostly related to MongoDB, where she currently works!) Anna is all about good food, traveling, and open source software!

Ben Darnell
=========
Ben Darnell is co-founder and CTO of Cockroach Labs, where he works with a team building an open-source distributed database in Go. He is also the maintainer of Tornado, an open source asynchronous web framework for Python. His career has spanned Google, Facebook, Dropbox, Square, and several smaller startups as both a consumer and developer of open source software.

David Turner
==========
David Turner hacks on Git at Twitter. He has previously worked for OpenPlans and the Free Software Foundation.

Julian Berman
==========
Julian is the Director of Platform Engineering at Magnetic (http://www.magnetic.com/). He's a testing lover, the author of jsonschema (an implementation of the JSON Schema validation specification for Python - http://pypi.python.org/pypi/jsonschema), and a contributor to various open source projects including Twisted (http://twistedmatrix.com/). He also can also be found most hours of the day as tos9 on Freenode in more channels than he can count, including #python.

Maia McCormick
=============
Born and raised in New York City, Maia graduated from Williams College in 2014 with a B.A. in music, tripped and fell, and landed in the tech industry by way of the Recurse Center (formerly known as Hacker School). At RC--a 3-month self-directed programmers’ retreat--she taught herself Python and pursued a handful of personal projects. Her first foray into the OSS world came in the form of an internship with GNOME via the Outreach Program for Women, for which she spent three months hacking on GNOME Music. Maia is currently a software engineer at Spring, a mobile shopping app based in NYC. Outside of programming, her interests include singing, dancing, and good food.
results.name: Tales of Open Source: Five Contributors, Five Stories

results.description:
Michael Hopkins will present the key points of his new book to be published by Greenleaf, UK in November 2015.

Rebecca Marsh, Publishing Director, GSE Research and Greenleaf Publishing writes:

Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) is steadily moving from the margins to the mainstream across the spectrum of private companies, NGOs and the public sector. It has grown from being a concept embraced by a small number of companies such as The Body Shop in the early 1990s to a widespread global movement. At its weakest level, it is represented by a few philanthropic gestures by organisations, but when applied in its most complete form, it can steer the organization or sector to deliver a fully-fledged, system-wide, multi-stakeholder operation, accompanied by multiple types of certification.

For the first time, a book brings together key issues relating to CSR as they apply to different aspects of business; it is not another generalist title about CSR. Michael Hopkins, a leading expert in the field, is joined by a number of outstanding contributors to the book, to explain how CSR has evolved since the 1990s and to offer ground-breaking insights and practical and specific applications of the concept. For example, Mervyn King explains Integrating Reporting, Deborah Leipziger looks at CSR, Branding and the Supply Chain, George Starcher provides a framework for Socially Responsible Restructuring, and Adrian Henriques explores Social Accounting and Stakeholder Dialogue.

* A one-stop reference book for professionals and students of CSR

* Contributions from leading specialists in the application of CSR

* Translates well-established theories into practical tools

We have to make charge to ensure we have a properly set up room ($20). Happily we shall also offer soft drinks, wine and a quick bite. Kindly pay at the door.

From an investor that is only making a little extra money and still working for someone else, to a SUCCESSFUL Real Estate Investor who is in charge of how much he or she makes and has the option to never work for anyone else ever again. Gain a team of Investors, Real Estate Agents, Tax & Legal Professionals, Contractors and more, to really get your Business Started!

On THURSDAY we will discuss:

•  Our Recent Deals, and the steps we took to Complete them

•  Tax Write Offs and Creative Ways to Acquire Properties

•  Wholesaling, Fix and Flips, Buy and Holds, and more

We will:

•  Help you figure out how many properties You Personally Need to Acquire to Reach your Financial Goal

•  Discuss how you can be apart of our future Deals

•  Give you the opportunity to Network and share in the stories of New Investors and Seasoned Investors

•  And much, much more

RSVP TO RECEIVE THE MEETING ADDRESS, FOR THIS THURSDAY AT 6:30PM!

“The critical ingredient is Getting off your Butt and Doing Something. It’s as simple as that. A lot of people have Ideas, but there are a Few who decide to Do Something about them Now. Not tomorrow. Not next week. But Today. The true Entrepreneur is a doer, not a dreamer.” – Noel Bushnell, Entrepreneur

“The Way to Get Started is to Quit talking and Begin Doing”  – Walt Disney, co-founder of the Walt Disney Company

Jurgis Orups, Co-Founder & CTO, Clusterpoint

RSVP NOW: http://www.NYCSQL.com/events/225397952/

A Database Month event:
http://www.DatabaseMonth.com/database/database-computing

Databases are typically utilized for storing data, but data is only useful if it is being turned into actionable insights. In this session we will explore an important adjacent-role of the database, to efficiently perform computations and create derived data.

Relational databases have been successful for several decades now because they provide a well defined computational framework, which is built on top of relational algebra. The relational algebra defines a set of operations that can be performed on the data.

However, times change and we are presently in a situation where relational databases do not easily scale to the amounts of data that businesses and organizations around the world are dealing with. NoSQL technology has emerged as an attempt to address this, but NoSQL loses the computational aspect. The majority of NoSQL databases are glorified key-value stores that support CRUD operations, but do not define a solid computational model.

Alternatively, MapReduce defines a computational framework to process large amounts of data, but has its own caveats. It encourages batch processing and full-scans of data, so the computation becomes detached from stored data.

It is our belief that the data management industry will move into the direction of consolidating storage, which will allow computing power and new databases to emerge; these will both scale to data storage needs as well as provide a solid online computational framework.

This session will teach you about a computing engine that is built into the database and allows arbitrary JavaScript-based code to be executed directly in the database, next to the data.

This setup provides a simple and powerful computational model that ensures data is accessed through efficient indices directly in the database, thus massively accelerating data manipulation operations.

Throughout this talk, we will present examples of how advanced computation can be done directly in the database, including an analysis of geospatial data, and the application of statistical model-like logistic regression to derive predictions.

Jurgis Orups, Co-Founder & CTO, Clusterpoint

Jurgis co-founded Clusterpoint in 2006.

Prior to that, he spent 6-years managing a team building large-scale Internet crawler and search technology. He specializes in parallel computing, text retrieval algorithms and natural language processing.

Jurgis has an MSc in Computer Science from the University of Latvia. When not at work, he enjoys photography and mountain biking, and even keeps a training bike in the office.

RSVP: http://www.NYCSQL.com/events/225397952/

Swag giveaway + food/drinks at 6:30pm 
Power-Networking at 6:35pm 
Presentation starts at 6:40pm

(saving child's life is very easy!)
